Saint.short_desc: Religious honorific for individuals officially recognized for holiness or virtue.

Sir.short_desc: Title given to male knights and baronets, particularly in British honors system.

Dame.short_desc: Female equivalent of knighthood in the British honors system.

Sri.short_desc: Indian honorific denoting respect, used for deities and revered persons.

Swami.short_desc: Hindu religious teacher or mystic, often heads religious order or monastery.

Rabbi.short_desc: Jewish religious leader and teacher qualified to interpret religious law.

Imam.short_desc: Islamic leadership position, leads prayers and provides religious guidance.

Reverend.short_desc: Christian clergy title, particularly for ordained ministers or priests.

Archbishop.short_desc: Senior bishop who oversees church affairs in a specified geographic area.

Cardinal.short_desc: Senior ecclesiastical leader in Catholic Church, ranks below Pope.

His/Her Majesty.short_desc: Form of address for monarchs, particularly kings and queens.

His/Her Highness.short_desc: Royal title used for princes, princesses, and some sovereign rulers.

Sheikh.short_desc: Arab leader or elder, can be political, religious, or tribal authority.

Professor.short_desc: Academic title for senior teaching and research position at university.

Doctor.short_desc: Title for those holding doctorate or medical degree, medical practitioners.

Rinpoche.short_desc: Tibetan Buddhist honorific meaning 'precious one', for reincarnated lamas.

Ayatollah.short_desc: High-ranking Shiite religious leader and Islamic legal authority.

Venerable.short_desc: Buddhist title for ordained monks and nuns, also used in Anglican Church.

Grand Master.short_desc: Highest rank in military and chivalric orders, some fraternal organizations.

Emperor/Empress.short_desc: Supreme monarch ruling over empire or multiple kingdoms.

Sultan.short_desc: Sovereign ruler in Islamic countries, historically Ottoman Empire.

Maharaja.short_desc: Great king in India, historically ruler of princely state.

Dalai Lama.short_desc: Spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism, traditionally temporal ruler of Tibet.

Pope.short_desc: Supreme head of Roman Catholic Church and sovereign of Vatican City.

Chief.short_desc: Traditional leader of tribe or community, particularly in indigenous societies.

Elder.short_desc: Respected community leader, often in indigenous or religious contexts.

Guru.short_desc: Spiritual teacher or master in Hindu tradition, expert guide.

Patriarch.short_desc: Head of Eastern Orthodox churches or ancient Christian sees.

Metropolitan.short_desc: Senior Orthodox or Eastern Catholic bishop of a major city.

Acharya.short_desc: Spiritual teacher or guide in Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain traditions.

Mr.short_description: Basic honorific for men, regardless of marital status.

Ms.short_description: Modern honorific for women regardless of marital status.

Mx.short_description: Gender-neutral honorific used as alternative to gendered titles.

Captain.short_description: Military or maritime rank, commander of ship or company.

Colonel.short_description: Senior military officer rank between Lieutenant Colonel and Brigadier.

General.short_description: Senior military rank, usually commanding large formations or forces.

Admiral.short_description: Senior naval officer rank, commands fleets or naval operations.

Lord.short_description: Noble title in British peerage system, also used for senior judges.

Lady.short_description: Female noble title, or courtesy title for daughter of peer.

Count/Countess.short_description: European noble rank equivalent to British Earl.

Duke/Duchess.short_description: Highest ranking noble title below monarch in British peerage.

Baron/Baroness.short_description: Lowest rank of hereditary British peerage.

Esquire.short_description: Courtesy title often used for lawyers in US, historically for gentlemen.

Right Honorable.short_description: British formal title for certain high officials and peers.

Honorable.short_description: Title for judges, politicians, and other officials in various countries.

Dean.short_description: Academic administrator heading faculty or division of university.

Chancellor.short_description: Head of university or senior government official in some countries.

President.short_description: Head of state, organization, or institution.

Vice President.short_description: Deputy to president in government, corporate, or institutional context.

Minister.short_description: Senior government official heading ministry or department.

Ambassador.short_description: Diplomatic representative of highest rank from one state to another.

Judge.short_description: Official with authority to preside over courts and make legal decisions.

Justice.short_description: Title for judges of supreme or superior courts.

Principal.short_description: Head of school or educational institution.

Director.short_description: Person in charge of organization, department, or artistic production.

Chairman/Chairwoman.short_description: Leader of board, committee, or organization.

His/Her Excellency.short_description: Diplomatic title for ambassadors, governors, and high officials.

Mahatma.short_description: Sanskrit title meaning 'Great Soul', given to spiritually advanced persons.

Monsignor.short_description: Honorific for certain Catholic priests given special recognition.

Archdeacon.short_description: Senior position in Christian churches, especially Anglican.

Brother/Sister.short_description: Religious title for members of Christian religious orders.

Mahatma.short_description: Sanskrit title meaning 'Great Soul', given to spiritually advanced persons.

Maharishi.short_description: Great sage or seer in Hindu tradition, one with divine insight.

Roshi.short_description: Senior Zen Buddhist teacher, literally 'old master' or 'respected teacher'.

Lama.short_description: Tibetan Buddhist spiritual teacher, literally 'highest principle'.

Bhagavan.short_description: Hindu term for Supreme Being or one possessed of divine qualities.

Sufi.short_description: Islamic mystic following spiritual path to divine love and wisdom.

Padre.short_description: Catholic priest or spiritual father figure in Latin traditions.

Monsignor.short_description: Honorific for certain Catholic priests given special recognition.

Brother/Sister.short_description: Religious title for members of Christian religious orders.

Fakir.short_description: Islamic or Hindu religious ascetic, often with mystical powers.

Dervish.short_description: Muslim mystic known for ascetic practices and spiritual exercises.

Sadhu.short_description: Hindu holy person who has renounced worldly life for spiritual pursuit.

Yogi/Yogini.short_description: Practitioner of yoga, one dedicated to spiritual and mental disciplines.

Bhikkhu/Bhikkhuni.short_description: Fully ordained Buddhist monk or nun.

Mullah.short_description: Muslim religious teacher or leader trained in Islamic law.

Pir.short_description: Sufi spiritual guide and mystic master in Islamic tradition.

Bodhisattva.short_description: Buddhist term for enlightened being who helps others achieve enlightenment.

Zen Master.short_description: Advanced teacher in Zen Buddhism tradition.

Elder.short_description: Spiritual leader in various religious traditions, respected for wisdom.

Mystic.short_description: One who has direct experience of divine or transcendent reality.

Sage.short_description: Person venerated for profound wisdom and spiritual insight.

Seer.short_description: Person with prophetic or mystical insight, visionary.

Prophet.short_description: Person regarded as divinely inspired teacher or proclaimer of will of God.

Avatar.short_description: Divine incarnation or manifestation in Hindu tradition.

Shaman.short_description: Spiritual healer and mediator between human and spirit worlds.

Medicine Man/Woman.short_description: Traditional healer combining spiritual and natural healing practices.

Holy One.short_description: Person recognized for exceptional spiritual attainment or sanctity.

Enlightened One.short_description: Being who has achieved highest spiritual realization or awakening.

Master.short_description: Advanced spiritual teacher who has mastered particular tradition.

Ascended Master.short_description: Being believed to have transcended physical existence through spiritual evolution.
